body_html:
@cpuhrsch I'm just starting to use pytorch so I'm not able to tell if this is a regression.

This is a snippet equivalent to what I'm doing:

for k in range(10):
    x = torch.zeros(50, 6000)
    a = torch.rand(6000, 6000)
    b = torch.rand(6000, 6000)
    c = torch.rand(6000)

    x[-1] = torch.rand(6000)
    for i in range(50-2, -1, -1):
        x[i] = torch.nn.functional.tanh(x[i+1]@a + x[i+1]@b + c)

    print(k)

Actually, now that I wrote this demo script it doesn't seem that slow, but I have no way to know if the matrix multiplications are being parallelised or not: get_num_threads is still 1.

body:
@cpuhrsch I'm just starting to use pytorch so I'm not able to tell if this is a regression.

This is a snippet equivalent to what I'm doing:

```python
for k in range(10):
    x = torch.zeros(50, 6000)
    a = torch.rand(6000, 6000)
    b = torch.rand(6000, 6000)
    c = torch.rand(6000)

    x[-1] = torch.rand(6000)
    for i in range(50-2, -1, -1):
        x[i] = torch.nn.functional.tanh(x[i+1]@a + x[i+1]@b + c)

    print(k)
```

Actually, now that I wrote this demo script it doesn't seem *that* slow, but I have no way to know if the matrix multiplications are being parallelised or not: get_num_threads is still 1.
